items.description: River Trent from Cromwell Weir to Gainsborough

items.message:
Flooding is possible in this area. 
 
Monitor local water levels and weather conditions. Avoid using low lying footpaths or entering areas prone to flooding. Start acting on your flood plan if you have one.
The Environment Agency Flood Warning System has issued this message based on rising river or tidal levels.  
 
We are temporarily automating our messages due to industrial action

River levels are high but slowly falling at the Pillings Lock river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall. Flooding continues. Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Slash Lane at Sileby and the Mountsorrel to Sileby road. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated as the situation changes.

Flooding is expected in this area. This means properties are at risk of flooding. Please take action to protect yourself and your property and monitor local weather and river conditions. Avoid contact with, walking or driving through flood water. Consider activating any property flood protection products you may have. The Environment Agency Flood Warning System has issued this message based on rising river or tidal levels. We are temporarily automating our messages due to industrial action.

items.description: Tidal River Ouse from Naburn Lock to Selby
Hundred Foot Washes in Cambridgeshire and Norfolk

floodArea.riverOrSea: Old Bedford River, New Bedford River, Hundred Foot Drain, River Delph

items.message: Water levels have risen across the Washes in response to recent heavy rain and snow melt. This has led to water covering the causeways. We expect water levels to slowly drop over the coming days and we will liaise with the relevant highways authorities as the situation changes.

This Flood Alert has been removed. River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold. There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain. 
We continue to monitor the situation. Please see the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast.

items.description: River Dee catchment in England from Whitchurch to Chester

floodArea.county: Cheshire West and Chester, Flintshire, Shropshire, Wrexham

items.message: We believe there is a possibility of flooding for low lying land and roads around the River Dee at Shocklach, Farndon, Handley, Lower Kinnerton, Chester and Puddington. Recent rainfall has caused the River Dee to rise. However, it has now reached its peak and will steadily fall through the weekend, but it will remain above the Flood Alert level until early next week. We are closely monitoring the situation. This message will be updated Monday morning, 20/03/2023, or as the situation changes. Please be aware of your surroundings and keep up to date with the current situation.

items.description: River Great Ouse in Cambridgeshire from Brampton to Earith
items.message:
Flooding is possible in this area.

Monitor local water levels and weather conditions. Avoid using low lying footpaths or entering areas prone to flooding. Start acting on your flood plan if you have one.

Environment Agency Flood Warning Officers set the river or tidal levels that have triggered this message. During industrial action this message has been automatically issued based on rising river or tidal levels.

We have seen heavy rainfall and snow melt in the River Nene area. This means that the River Nene has risen, which has led to flooding of low-lying land and roads close to the river. We expect the river to remain high over the next few days and flooding to gardens, driveways or out buildings is possible close to the river. We are constantly monitoring river levels. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated as the situation changes.
